column4: can u pls recommend me a gui client for ssh transfers? (i.e. scp?)
Use scp in a GUI terminal window.  (See man ssh)
which was what i was trying to avoid as i have so many files in so many different folders to copy...
You can do them all at once. Which folders?
i am copying the contents of ldap related files for documentation purposes, meaning pma.d etc involved...
You can create a ziped archived file and then transfer it.
well i actually did not want to include all of etc, and hand picking it brings me back to square one concerning effort...
Pici: jrib: dnivra: anyways thanks alot, i got what i need now:)
I don't think a GUI interface would make the process any faster or easier.
well it does trust me;)
Well, then you could set up an ftp server on one end and use a browser to do it.  But that seems a rather clumsy alternative.
nope, easiest method so far was the one sugfgested by dnivra; just go to places/connect to server, that does it for me!:)
tar czvf data.tgz dir-1/ dir-1/ dir-3 ; scp data.tgz user@192.168.1.5   #What is easier than that?
Well, yes, if you have a server on the other machine, but then you have to select all the data you want to transfer.
tar czvf data.tgz dir-1/ dir-1/ dir-3 ; scp data.tgz user@192.168.1.5:     #Forgot the colon at end, thanks elFidel
Or tar czvf data.tgz dir-1/ dir-1/ dir-3 ; scp data.tgz user@192.168.1.5:Documents/
do it for 38 files located in 25 different folders, wish you much fun with forgetting nothing;)
I don't see how some browser looking GUI window is going to help you remember all 38 files any better than using ssh in a GUI terminal
But if you have found a good method that you like, go for it.  I'm just trying to suggest what I believe to be the most effecient method.
Once you learn how to use the tab key to auto-complete, it will be a breeze, (but maybe you already know but just fyi..)
